ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my literary analysis and writing skills.  I also got an overview of literature from Cervantes to Derek Walcott.
I learned how to analyze literature, write not only critical analysis about texts but how they relate to the current world/past time periods and how I feel about them...
I learned to analyze literature more deeply and draw connections across different parts of a text. I also gained a deeper appreciation for literature and came to enjoy it as an art form.

I really developed my writing abilities and my ability to participate in in-class discussion. Particularly, I learned how to interact personally with the text in my analyses and curate my in-class comments to best add to the conversation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the texts!  They're amazing, and they stimulate such fascinating discussions.  Professor Handler Spitz is also a great strength of the course.  

Weaknesses: I don't think there is anything that can be done about this, but the reading load is uneven: some weeks you'll have 350 pages to read for Lit, and other weeks only 100.  This also means that some books get covered in a lot more detail than others.  

I also think DS should rethink its final exams.  I get that timed essays are the classic exam format.  But it's a little jarring because DS teaches you one skill -- how to write a paper on a narrow topic over the course of a week -- and then tests you on a completely different one -- how to write timed essays covering lots of authors at once.  I don't think timed essay exams are really true to the spirit of DS, which asks you to think deeply about texts and let them sit with you.  Moreover, I don't think they are a good learning experience, especially for a remote semester.  I think that the pandemic was the an opportunity to rethink how DS students can synthesize their knowledge at the end of the semester.  Maybe DS can still change for a future year.

The reading selection for Spring DS Lit is pretty interesting with works that are very important to the Western canon. This course was also probably more work than most of my other DS classes because of the weekly reading responses in addition to papers and discussions.

The syllabus is a strength of this course. I enjoyed all the texts and found them to be interesting and worth reading. The reading load can be quite heavy at times, but the quality of the books and seminar conversations makes it rewarding to complete it all.

The strengths of this course are definitely the in-class discussion and the detailed feedback we received on our essays. The main weaknesses of the course related to the fact that it was taught online, so the Zoom format sometimes affected our communication and interaction.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course didn't have many practices particularly for the pandemic (at least that I can think of). I think things adapted well on Zoom.
I thought discussions, albeit pretty formal, were okay. We just had a lot of technology issues that made it difficult to keep up a lot of the time.
The virtual seminar format was optimal considering the pandemic learning environment. It was still easy to engage with the class and participate.

I actually think recorded lectures are superior in many ways to those that are live and in-person. I enjoy being able to watch the lecture at my leisure and stop/start it as necessary, although it isn't possible to ask questions. Obviously, Zoom seminars are inferior to in-person, but it works relatively well and I don't see how they could be improved.

I thought that the recorded lectures worked pretty well, and Zoom made it very easy and convenient for one-on-one meetings with Prof. Handler-Spitz. However, I think that the Zoom format at times hindered the flow of the in-class discussions and made us feel a bit disconnected because we were all in our separate rooms.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!!  I absolutely loved Lit this semester.  The texts are particularly phenomenal in the last month or two.  I'd also recommend the course especially with Professor Handler Spitz, who was my favorite professor this semester.  She is so kind and cares about all her students.  She always emphasizes how literature is personal and emotional -- not just something to be picked apart -- and she gives amazing feedback.

Yeah, I mean if you're going to take DS you will have to take this course, but I will say I enjoyed it more than fall DS Lit. If you put a significant amount of work in between the reading and assignments, you'll be fine.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. All the texts we read are masterfully written. Anyone can derive a great deal of insight and enjoyment from them, regardless of whether they plan on studying literature further in the future.
Yes--I feel I really expanded the way that I interact with the text and reached new levels of interpretation and analysis. I also gained a lot of confidence in my writing and discussion skills.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: (seminar and lectures, both virtual)
Virtual seminar with recorded lectures
recorded lecture
Recorded lecture
recorded lecture
